awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Anatomy of a Greenhouse World: The Early Eocene of the Green River Basin, Wyoming
awd_abstract_narration:
The geologic record of past environmental change offers an illuminating glimpse into the behavior of Earth's natural systems.  The deposits formed in ancient lakes are particularly useful in this regard for several reasons:  they are highly sensitive to climate change; they often contain relatively complete geologic archives with relatively few gaps; and they can potentially be used to document changes that occurred over time scales meaningful to humans.  The Green River Formation in the western U.S. offers an especially valuable record of the most geologically recent period of prolonged greenhouse conditions, which occurred approximately 50-53 million years ago during the Eocene Epoch.  It is famous for its rich assemblages of fossil vertebrates, insects, and plants, and for containing the world's largest commercial deposits of soda ash and oil shale.  This research project will focus on evidence for repeated rapid warming events during this time, by examining how river courses changed, the types of sediment that accumulated within the lake, and variations in ancient soil development and chemistry.  Equally important, this study will build a time scale of unprecedented accuracy and precision for these important deposits, based on new radiometric dates of volcanic ash in the lake, the chronology of changes in the Earth's magnetic field, and sedimentation patterns that were driven by periodic oscillations in the Earth's rotation and orbit.  Broader impacts of this proposal will include development of local 2-hour field trips for middle and high school students, enhanced through the use of innovative data visualization technology on portable devices.   

The Early Eocene Climatic Optimum (EECO) was a time of persistent global warmth, of which the cause remains incompletely determined.  Lake deposits of the Green River Formation preserve a rich and previously untapped record that complements that contained in marine sediments, and present an opportunity to advance the precision and accuracy of the Early Eocene timescale.  This project is an integrated, multidisciplinary investigation focused on one of the world's richest and best studied systems of ancient lake strata. The research will investigate three principal questions: 1. How did the timing of terrestrial warming compare to that inferred from the marine record, and to predicted patterns of the Earth's orbital variations?  Recent advances in radioisotopic dating can be used to directly test the relationship of warming events to Earth's orbital changes, and calibrate dynamic gravitational models of the solar system back to ca. 50 million years. 2. How did temperatures, seasonality, hydrologic cycling, and weathering on land evolve during the EECO? One hypothesis is that warming was amplified on continents relative to the oceans and was accompanied by more equable temperatures year-round, whereas precipitation seasonality and intensity increased. 3. How did the complex tectonic and magmatic evolution of western North America impact the preservation of EECO climate signals?  The research will test the hypothesis that repeated, stepwise drainage reorganizations within the tectonically-active uplands modified the hydrologic balance and sedimentary deposits of the Eocene lake environment and its response to orbital changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For this award, Anatomy of a Greenhouse World: The Early Eocene of the Green River Basin Wyoming (#1813703), we proposed to address critical questions regarding Eocene (~50 million years ago) climate through an integrated, multidisciplinary investigation that focuses on one of the world's richest and best studied systems of ancient lake strata. Specifically, we investigated how major global warming events were recorded in terrestrial environments in the past, and how those conditions can help us understand the evolution of important climate features (e.g., temperature seasonality, the hydrologic cycle) into the future under anthropogenic warming.

Our multidisciplinary team of scientists, educators, and students from 7 universities in the United States worked for 5+ years to build a series of crucial datasets, from a detailed and comprehensive stratigraphic and sedimentological framework of the Green River Basin (GRB), to the most robust terrestrial geochronology of a deep-time basin in existence, to novel paleoclimate archives and geochemical techniques, to compiling perhaps the best available analogue of future high-emissions scenario climates. Over the course of the award, we uncovered a series of key insights into past climate and climate archives, including that authigenic carbonates (e.g., stromatolites, lake carbonates, soil carbonates) are highly consistent proxy archives; that the Early Eocene Climatic Optimum (EECO) was characterized by large shifts in temperature, hydrologic cycling, and seasonality in continental environments; that the GRB was surrounded by high-elevation peaks with varying water sources over the course of the EECO due to the complex interplay of climate and tectonics; and that linked terrestrial and marine archives provide a comprehensive record of past conditions for specific comparison to modern and future climate states. Overall, we found that the uniquely high spatial and temporal resolution of the records provided by the GRB are unparalleled in past climate archives, and that it is possible to reconstruct climate and environmental variability during important greenhouse periods as a ‘natural laboratory’ for the future.

In addition to the scientific impacts of this award, we have provided myriad opportunities for broader impacts in society. Perhaps one of the most important is our efforts to train the next generation of Earth scientists; multiple graduate students from diverse and underrepresented backgrounds were directly trained and mentored via this research, preparing them for continuing careers in STEM fields. This research also was and will continue to be used in graduate and undergraduate teaching at a wide range of universities, especially given the ongoing public archiving of case study materials from this work. Furthermore, this work has improved existing research infrastructure at a major public university, expanding future capacity for basic research, STEM training, and scientific discovery. This research is also likely to impact public knowledge about climate science and impacts of global change, as broad dissemination and concerted efforts by the PIs to provide this information to the public has been an important goal. This research is also likely to provide background for future climate predictions (e.g., IPCC reports), as most current climate prediction models are developed based on or validated using paleoclimate archives; because the early Eocene is an important analogue period, it is commonly used for considering future scenarios and may serve as a key set of "avoidance" criteria for climate policy decisions as such decision-making becomes more commonplace.

This award has resulted in over a dozen scientific publications and presentations in professional settings, as well as a series of teaching modules at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and public primers on climate and Earth history, information for which can be found in common public repositories and on the website of the Paleo3 Research Group at NC State.
